newsitem.title: USA: No de minimis repeal seen on the horizon - Nuveen.
newsitem.headline: No de minimis repeal seen on the horizon - Nuveen.

text.p: The U.S. Congress has little incentive to repeal the two percent "de minimis" rule since such a move would raise little, if any, revenues for federal coffers, a John Nuveen & Co. official said in a report.
President Clinton in his proposed fiscal 1998 federal budget called for repeal of a series of corporate tax "loopholes" in the U.S. tax code, including the de minimis rule.

But Cadmus Hicks, vice president in Nuveen Research, said in four-page analysis that U.S. Treasury Department estimates of how much the federal government would make from repeal have declined considerably over the past two years.

"The last time the administration made this proposal (in 1996), the U.S. Treasury Department estimated that repeal would increase federal tax revenues by $500 million over the next seven years as corporations switch to taxable investments," Hicks said.
President Clinton's latest proposed budget, however, estimates that repeal only would increase revenues by $200 million over the next five years, Hicks said.

"It would not raise very much money. In fact there is a question whether it would result in any increase in federal revenues," Hicks said in a telephone interview. As a result, this proposal "may eventually be rejected" by Capitol Hill, Hicks said.
Currently, individuals can fall into one of four tax brackets - 28 percent, 31 percent, 36 percent or 39.6 percent," Hicks said. But before 1993, the top bracket was only 31 percent, he said.
"Then, you could be sure that if corporations were no longer able to hold (tax-exempt bonds) they would be held by people in a 31 percent tax bracket," he said.

"But, now, since we have a 36 percent and 39.6 percent tax bracket, it's not a sure thing. You may actually have these securities going out of the hands of corporations into the hands of retail customers who actually get a bigger write off because they are in a higher bracket," Hicks said.
Currently, the Internal Revenue Service does not permit businesses to deduct interst on debt that they use to finance the purchase of tax exempt bonds.

But, the IRS said in 1972, in what is dubbed the de minimis rule, that it will not monitor whether a corporation has borrowed to purchase tax-exempt bonds as long as those holdings total less than two percent of a firm's net assets.
